title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

items.title: The Trump tariffs are forcing CEOs to lead through uncertainty. Here’s how the best executives guide their teams in tough times
items.description: The Fortune Best Companies to Work For list features businesses whose leaders keep employees loyal and motivated.

items.title: Foreign college students are now losing their visas and being ordered to leave over misdemeanor crimes or traffic infractions
items.description: A crackdown on foreign students is alarming colleges, who say the Trump administration is using new tactics and vague justifications to push some stud...

items.title: Analysts unanimously denounce Trump’s liberation day tariffs: ‘Worse than the worst case’
items.description: Analysts at Wedbush Securities and Goldman Sachs as well as top economist Larry Summers predicted much economic pain ahead.

items.title: NYC Mayor Eric Adams will run for reelection as an independent after deal with Trump DOJ to drop his corruption charges
items.description: The mayor, who had not formed much of a formal reelection apparatus, has struggled to raise money in recent months.

items.title: Trump’s Trade War Escalates as China Retaliates With 34% Tariffs
items.description: The Chinese government said it would match President Trump’s tariff, and also barred a group of American companies from doing business in China.

items.title: Trump Officials Warn of Tariff Pain as Price Increases Loom and Stocks Tumble
items.description: The president’s aides insist the fallout will be short and ultimately result in a better economy, as economists warn of higher inflation and slower gr...

items.title: Invasion of the Home Humanoid Robots
items.description: Dozens of companies are building robots that look like humans. One of them is training a machine to be a butler and will soon test them in homes.

items.title: Gen. Timothy Haugh Ousted as Head of NSA and Cyber Command
items.description: No reason was given for the removal of Gen. Timothy D. Haugh. The far-right activist Laura Loomer had called for his ouster in a meeting with Presiden...

items.title: Senate GOP advance Trump’s ‘big’ bill of tax breaks and spending cuts as tariffs put economy on edge
items.description: What's unclear is how it will all be paid for, since Republican deficit hawks typically require spending offsets to help defray the lost tax revenue a...

items.title: Europe’s Paradox
items.description: We explain a development that may help the far right in Europe.

items.title: Jubilation in South Korea After President Who Declared Martial Law Is Ousted
items.description: The nation’s top court unanimously upheld the impeachment of Yoon Suk Yeol, clearing the way for the election of a new president.

items.title: India Passes Contentious Bill Increasing Oversight of Muslim Land Trusts
items.description: The legislation passed by Parliament on Friday would allow non-Muslims to help administer so-called Waqfs. The move fueled concerns that the rights of...

items.title: As Unexplained Quakes Ease, Santorini Insists It’s Open for Business
items.description: The Greek island was shaken by thousands of mostly smaller-scale temblors. Now, residents have returned, and they hope visitors will, too.

items.title: Trump’s Trade War Escalates as China Retaliates With 34% Tariffs
items.description: The Chinese government said it would match President Trump’s tariff, and also barred a group of American companies from doing business in China.

items.title: What Is Next for Yoon Suk Yeol, South Korea’s Ousted President?
items.description: South Korea’s former president still faces criminal charges of leading an insurrection when he declared martial law. If found guilty, he could be impr...
